In 1948, at the Annual meeting of the NAEB on the campus of the
University of Illinois, Richard B, Hull, then President of the NAEB,
called upon the organisation to raise its sights and become a more con¬
structive force in education if it wished to deserve support as a gen¬
uinely educational service. The trade press at that time carried conjec¬
tures as to whether this young organisation would foe able to survive the
struggle between the *‘status quo" group, which saw itself essentially
as broadcasters, and the ^progresslve’Woup, which saw itself essen¬
tially as educators.
By a margin which was not as great as we would wish, the asso¬
ciation voted to support new goals for the NAEB, and to seek Foundation
support to assist in their achievement,
At the same time the NAEB voted to request the reservation of
television channels for education. In the ensuing few years, the NAEB
was able to rally the support of other organisations for this effort, which
culminated first, in the formation of the Joint Council on Educational
Tele\dsion, of which Mr, Hull was the first Executive Director; and
secondly, in the actual allocation for education of 257 channels in the
TV spectrum for education’s own national television service •
Thanks to the efforts of Dr« Wilbur Schramm, then Dean of Commun¬
ications at the University of Illinois, on behalf also of the NAEB, funds
were secured from the Rockefeller Foundation to hold the 1949 Seminar,
mentioned above.
